10742: Lord of the Undead.author: Silverware
10742: Lord of the Undead.text_parsed:
Lord of the Undead is one of my personal favorite lords. A major contester for your 3 drops in any zombie deck.

I personaly run 4 of these in my mono-black zombie deck and really they are a must to keep your zombies from staying locked away in the graveyard. Also brining back a nameless inversion or a fleshbag marauder every turn can be pretty game changing as it often allows you to shut down your opponents creature generation altogther.

Also if you need more ways to bring back your zombies to put presure on the field consider unearth and unholy grotto.

Also brining back a [autocard]nameless inversion[/autocard] or a [autocard]fleshbag marauder[/autocard] every turn can be pretty game changing as it often allows you to shut down your opponents creature generation altogther.

Also if you need more ways to bring back your zombies to put presure on the field consider [autocard]unearth[/autocard] and [autocard]unholy grotto[/autocard].

10742: Lord of the Undead.author: ParallaxtheRevan
10742: Lord of the Undead.text_parsed:
I don't remember how many times it's ever happened, but this Is not the only occurrence in the game that a non-legendary card has represented a Named Character in the Story. This guy didn't ''become'' Dralnu, he flat out Is Dralnu, but he wasn't made Legendary because sometimes.....Legends didn't become Legends.

They were PRETTY good about it, but like between 1-5% of Legends got turned into non-Legendary cards.

This would never have happen again starting with Modern, I think. I wouldn't be surprised if people were able to find one or two more cards like this, though.

21305: Sunken Hope.author: HeavyElectricity
21305: Sunken Hope.text_parsed:
Back when Planeshift was new, a couple of people in my casual play group were playing a U/B control deck which included this, Warped Devotion and Megrim as a wacky win condition. The rest of it was centred around counter, bounce and discard spells - and of course, the Invasion block included neat things like Recoil. It was very slow but because the average skill level of the group wasn't so high, it didn't do too badly.

Of course, this was an era in which Tranquility was a staple card and Tranquil Grove was part of the core set. Once the mono-green beatdown players of the group figured out what to do, it was curtains for the poor old Sunken Hope deck and Blastoderm returned to being the dominant threat in our small group.

22298: Multani's Harmony.author: majinara
22298: Multani's Harmony.text_parsed:
If you can play creatures, you shouldn't have mana problems. And most creatures should have another purpose in your deck instead of beeing tapped for this aura.
Two things are good about this thing though: you can play it on creatures of teammates in team games, if they are manascrewed. Also, it has a slight combo potential. You can put it on creatures with untap-abitilies, like Surgespanner, and even generate mana this way. Still, most of the time, this card is just plain bad.

23051: Doomsday Specter.text_parsed: This is easily one of the best, if not the best, specter(s) out there.

23051: Doomsday Specter.author: majinara
23051: Doomsday Specter.text_parsed:
This guy is very powerful, but only if you make good use of his gating ability, using it to your advantage and not to your disadvantage.
Example:
Turn 3, play Man-o'-War.
Turn 4, attack with the manowar, then play this guy and return the manowar to your hand.
Turn 5, play manowar again, bouncing either a possible blocker of the specter, or simply the most annoying creature your opponent has. Then attack with the specter, and you can have him discard the creature you just bounced.

You can also use Chittering Rats instead of the jellyfish, setting your opponent two turns back. Or an Eternal Witness. Any creature with a good CIP ability is worth it.

23051: Doomsday Specter.author: Cyberium
23051: Doomsday Specter.text_parsed:
Things people might overlook in comparison to Shimian specter:

1) Doomsday Spector make your opponent discard ANY card, that include lands. (Although Shimian's denial power is definitely stronger)

2) You can return utility creatures to your hand with Doomsday Spector, such as Seagate Oracle, Man'o War, Ravenous Rats, Rune-Scarred Demon, etc.

3) 2/3 is slightly tougher against other 2 attack power flyers. Also at the time of this card's presence, there was no Bolt, only Shock.

25614: Ertai, the Corrupted.author: SavageBrain89
25614: Ertai, the Corrupted.text_parsed: I have seen a plethora of amazingly good cards before, and Ertai by far is probably one of the best. His ability is simply astounding, granted that you have several tokens in play or creatures (or enchantments) that you don't need, allowing you to control exactly what your opponent plays through-out the rest of the game. This definitely fits right in the with the esper colors; restrictive abilities that neutralize the opponent and allow you to control them. The only downside to Ertai is that if your not playing tokens or lost of enchantments then it can become quite difficult to use him effectively. Also Ertai's ability can only be played once per turn, but with cards like Thousand-Year Elixir and other untapping abilities this minor weakness can easily be overlooked.

25614: Ertai, the Corrupted.author: kitsunewarlock
25614: Ertai, the Corrupted.text_parsed:
Best used with enchantments that return to hand. Rancor is the most memorable but *not* the best for this guy. Mostly since its not in his colors. Better to use Brilliant Halo, Cessation, Despondency, Diabolic Servitude (For the creature, not the enchantment), Fool's Demise, Fallen Ideal, Launch, Sleeper's Guile, Slow Motion, and Spirit Loop.

See: 10 auras in his colors with the "Rancor" effect without having to splash green for Rancor. Several of them are quite playable too. Only reason people say "Auras stink" is because if the creature dies your out one whole card. If it was a negative-effect aura, you would have been better off controlling or killing it rather than weakening. But the auras I listed above are different. Since they come back they aren't disadvantageous (or at least AS disadvantageous).

All-in-all, his major advantage over Ertai 1.0 is the fact he is three colors, giving you more options in EDH. The {U} cost is much nicer than the {2}{U}{U} cost as well, leaving your mana openf or other counters.

He is great with Rule of Law/Arcane Lab. In multiplayer you still need an untap effect since your going to get a lot of hate with this combo. Fortunately blue is full of them. Freed from the Real and Penninen's Aura (sp?) is the best by far (aura has shroudy and pumpy too).

Since they come back they aren't disadvantageous (or at least AS disadvantageous).

All-in-all, his major advantage over Ertai 1.0 is the fact he is three colors, giving you more options in EDH.  The {U} cost is much nicer than the {2}{U}{U} cost as well, leaving your mana openf or other counters.

He is great with Rule of Law/Arcane Lab.  In multiplayer you still need an untap effect since your going to get a lot of hate with this combo.  Fortunately blue is full of them.  Freed from the Real and Penninen's Aura (sp?) is the best by far (aura has shroudy and pumpy too).

25614: Ertai, the Corrupted.author: Tonymitsu
25614: Ertai, the Corrupted.text_parsed:
1. Ertai, the Corrupted
2. Lullmage Mentor
3. Sea Scryer
4. Carnival of Souls
5. Intruder Alarm
6. Soul Warden


Other recommendations: A sacrificial creature to start the process.

The process:
A. The opponent casts a spell, you pay and sacrifice a creature to counter it.
B. Once this resolves, you just countered an opponents spell, so Lullmage Mentor activates giving you a creature token.
C. Since you just got a creature, Carnival of Souls takes 1 life, and gives you one black mana.
D. Again, since you just got a creature, Soul Warden gives you back the life you lost in Step C.
E. Yet again, since you just got a creature, Intruder Alarm untaps everything, including Ertai and the Sea Scryer
F. You have in your mana pool. If another spell is cast, tap the Sea Scryer to convert it to blue mana, activate Ertai, and proceed to Step A.
G. Ask your opponent if they would like to concede.

Soul Warden is basically optional in this whole equation, since without it this becomes "Pay 1 life: Counter target spell", which is still pretty insane in any deck which has white and thus potential life-gaining. Multiple Soul Wardens only make it more insane since you actually start coming out ahead in life each time you counter something.

There are tons of substitutions you can make to fit this basic equation into other decks. You can substitute Carnival of Souls for any creature that taps for mana, since Intruder Alarm will untap it along with Ertai and the Sea Scryer. I don't know of any other effects that can so efficiently untap things but if they are out there you can probably replace Intruder Alarm with them. The only real way to disrupt this is for two or more opponents to gang up on you and react to Ertai with another spell, which should be difficult since you only need 1 blue mana to begin this leaving plenty of mana open to play things from your hand. And as soon as the stack resolves the whole process starts all over.

Despite it's complicated for-or-six-card set up, the ability to negate virtually anything your opponent could possibly do to disrupt you is quite clearly "good game". Unfortunately, there are 19 cards in the game that are immune to this set up, and a deck that utilizes almost any one of them will ruin everything. Vexing Shusher gets a notable mention for this.

25614: Ertai, the Corrupted.author: NissasChosen
25614: Ertai, the Corrupted.text_parsed:
"Best used with enchantments that return to hand. Rancor is the most memorable but *not* the best for this guy. Mostly since its not in his colors. Better to use Brilliant Halo, Cessation, Despondency, Diabolic Servitude (For the creature, not the enchantment), Fool's Demise, Fallen Ideal, Launch, Sleeper's Guile, Slow Motion, and Spirit Loop.

See: 10 auras in his colors with the "Rancor" effect without having to splash green for Rancor. Several of them are quite playable too. Only reason people say "Auras stink" is because if the creature dies your out one whole card. If it was a negative-effect aura, you would have been better off controlling or killing it rather than weakening. But the auras I listed above are different. Since they come back they aren't disadvantageous (or at least AS disadvantageous).

All-in-all, his major advantage over Ertai 1.0 is the fact he is three colors, giving you more options in EDH. The {U} cost is much nicer than the {2}{U}{U} cost as well, leaving your mana open for other counters.

He is great with Rule of Law/Arcane Laboratory. In multiplayer you still need an untap effect since your going to get a lot of hate with this combo. Fortunately blue is full of them. Freed from the Real and Penim's Aura is the best by far (aura has shroudy and pumpy too)."

Re-posted with autocards for ease of use.

Also, @Tonymitsu, I like what you're thinking, but, you can cut your six card combo to four by replacing Carnival of Souls, Soul Warden, and Sea Scryer with a simple Silver Myr. And if you throw in a Teferi, Mage of Zhalfir it becomes a nearly unbreakable prison. I have an Ertai EDH deck that can pretty consistently put this together, and it's really sick.

That's a great question, and the answer is: No, it wouldn't. You see, this is one static ability that is checked when you cast a spell.
I) You're casting a spell. Is it black or green?
A>Yes.
1>Then it costs 1 less to play.
B>No.
1>Then you have to pay full cost.

If it's carefully worded into two abilities, like Grand Arbiter Augustin IV, then it costs 2 less to play, as two different static abilities are checked.

25646: Eladamri's Call.author: DarthParallax
25646: Eladamri's Call.text_parsed:
it's not banned in Commander, Legacy, Invasion Block, or its own Standard season (Invasion-Odyssey and Mercadian-Invasion). Considering Odyssey Block had Judgment set, a green-white focused set that included an extra non-basic land and the card Mirari's Wake, I'm quite surprised Eladamri's Call doesn't make into the Top Comments for that season.

It's Good and even Great, but I really don't think its banning in Prismatic counts as much for impressive points as you think. Like, Lingering Souls was banned in its Block Format. Which was an interesting Ban and affected people sure, but it wasn't anywhere close to needing to be banned in Standard. The only thing that makes me a little more interested is Prismatic is somewhat of a different animal than Block.

Isn't it a format that forces everyone's deck to be 5-colored? Question: is it "Eternal"- does it start with close to the same card pool as Legacy Vintage before you start factoring bans? This IS a Tutor, for 2 mana CMC, so, you know it's very interesting for that.

But less interesting than:

Vampiric Tutor
Intuition
Glittering Wish
Academy Rector


And it's not. Not really the best Creature Tutor ever printed. Let's be perfectly honest with ourselves here. Entomb is because it puts the creature into the zone easiest to move it to the battlefield from. Which is your graveyard, not your hand.

25871: Terminate.author: Leshrac_Nightwalker
25871: Terminate.text_parsed:
@Mata-nui3:
Actually, the self-styled "gods" that this card's flavour text mentions aren't the Phyrexians... they're the other dragon legends.

The five legendary dragons from Invasion were something akin to dragon gods - they had tyrannized Dominaria way back in the day, and they were so powerful that Dominaria's lesser races couldn't kill them... all they could do was imprison them. Darigaaz was looking for a way to combat the Phyrexians, and Tevesh Szat gave him some malicious advice, telling him that if he found and released the five superdragons, they would be more than powerful enough to fight off the invaders.

Once Darigaaz did release the other four (finding out, in the process, that he was the reincarnation of the "red one"), they essentially became invulnerable, and they started attacking the Phyrexians... but once the tide had turned in favour of the defenders, the dragons started slaughtering Dominarians as punishment for their long imprisonment. Rith, Treva, Dromar and Crosis intended to rebuild their lost dragon empire, and Darigaaz, knowing that nothing could stop them while all five were flying, sacrificed himself to make the others vulnerable again.
25871: Terminate.text_posted:
@Mata-nui3:
Actually, the [i]self-styled "gods"[/i] that this card's flavour text mentions aren't the Phyrexians... they're [autocard multiverseid="23206"]the[/autocard] [autocard multiverseid="23207"]other[/autocard] [autocard multiverseid="209121"]dragon[/autocard] [autocard multiverseid="209118"]legends[/autocard].  

The five legendary dragons from Invasion were something akin to dragon gods - they had tyrannized Dominaria way back in the day, and they were so powerful that Dominaria's lesser races couldn't kill them... all they could do was imprison them.  Darigaaz was looking for a way to combat the Phyrexians, and Tevesh Szat gave him some [autocard]malicious advice[/autocard], telling him that if he found and released the five superdragons, they would be more than powerful enough to fight off the invaders.  

Once Darigaaz did release the other four (finding out, in the process, that he was the reincarnation of the "red one"), they essentially became invulnerable, and they started attacking the Phyrexians... but once the tide had turned in favour of the defenders, the dragons started slaughtering Dominarians as punishment for their long imprisonment.  Rith, Treva, Dromar and Crosis intended to rebuild their lost dragon empire, and Darigaaz, knowing that nothing could stop them while all five were flying, sacrificed himself to make the others vulnerable again.

If I see someone play this, though, I might be inclined to keep a bunch of lands in my hand to up the chances of them paying four mana to activate an ability that accomplished nothing besides letting them see I have land in my hand.

25913: Stormscape Battlemage.author: majinara
25913: Stormscape Battlemage.text_parsed:
@ Neutralion
Wikipedia says:
Part of the planeswalker Urza's plans to repel the inevitable Phyrexian Invasion involved the creation of a specially-bred army of soldiers. Dubbed the "Metathran" in honor of the long-lost Thran civilization, Urza's warriors were genetically engineered to be decisive, unerring and obedient, with superhuman combat skills and tactical awareness. Though the Thran themselves were primarily Caucasian, the Metathran had a distinctive light-blue hue and a tall, gangly appearance. They appeared male, but in fact had no gender, as they would have no need to breed. Most of the Metathran were designed to blindly follow orders, however, two generals had been specifically designed to act on their own. Thaddeus and Agnate had a symbiotic, near-telepathic connection to each other and depended on each other to function. Intended to fight the Phyrexian menace and nothing else, the Metathran were freely expendable, and none survived the war. "Metathran" was not originally a supported creature type in the game, but became one with the release of the 10th Edition Core Set in July 2007.

25913: Stormscape Battlemage.author: TheWrathofShane
25913: Stormscape Battlemage.text_parsed:
Ouch....
1) Without kickers is just a 2/2 for which is bad.
2) With just a white its a 2/2 for +3 life which is bad.
3) With black its a 2/2 for + destroy which is bad.
4) With ultimate its a 2/2 for +3 life + destroy which is bad.

Your really not going to want to preform options 1 or 2, unless your desperate. So you can hardly take those two options into account when rating this card.
If you can get setup with a repeatable bounce and a ton of mana, sure you can destroy a creature every turn.... Or you can just play Visara the Dreadful, your call.

Final rating: 2/5

25914: Nightscape Battlemage.author: majinara
25914: Nightscape Battlemage.text_parsed:
Expensive, but powerful. Bouncing two creatures is strong anyway, and killing a land to make it harder for your opponent to replay them has nice synergy with it. Why you cant bounce black creatures? Well, play this guy with both kickers, while having something in play that changes his color, such as celestial dawn. Then destroy a land with the red ability, choose an opponents creature and himself with the blue ability, and return him this way back to hand. In short: you could keep destroying your opponents lands and bouncing his creatures over and over as much as you have mana.
Expensive? Yes. But the designers were obviously still worried enough about this possibility.
25914: Nightscape Battlemage.text_posted:

25918: Urza's Guilt.text_posted: So can you actually play the cards you draw if they're instants?

25918: Urza's Guilt.author: Mode
25918: Urza's Guilt.text_parsed:
@Schnappi: No, you can't.
The "madness cards" he was talking about are cards with an ability (Madness) that allows you to play them for a special mana cost (most often being cheaper than the casting cost) at the time you discard them from your hand.

Cards like the infamous Psychatog are much better for such decks though, since 1. discarding the cards for it doesn't require any mana (after playing Urza's Guilt there shouldn't be much mana left unless you play it in the late game) and 2. the discarded cards are used for a more useful effect; to pump that creature.

25918: Urza's Guilt.author: Andon_A
25918: Urza's Guilt.text_parsed:
This sounds fun if you have Megrim, Liliana's Caress, and Underworld Dreams out. 2 damage from underworld dreams, then 6 damage each from Megrim and Liliana's Caress, then 4 damage from the card itself. That's a total of 18 damage for this card. And if you have more Megrims/Caresses out, well, you're in an even better position.

EDIT: Oh, and you can get this fourth turn.

First turn: Swamp, Dark Ritual, Underworld Dreams
Second turn: Swamp OR Island, Liliana's Caress
Third turn: Swamp OR Island, Megrim
Fourth Turn: Swamp OR Island, Urza's Guilt.

As long as you play one island, they're dead, since they take at least two damage from Underworld Dreams even if you go second. Plus, this kills everyone BUT you regardless of the number of players, since this affects everyone. That's nasty.

25926: Cavern Harpy.author: bijart_dauth
25926: Cavern Harpy.text_parsed: i saw a legacy winning deck that was capable of drawing there entire deck turn 1 or 2 useing this, wirewood savage, and aluren. It used Elvish Spirit Guides and lotus petal to get aluren out earlier and then bounces itself to draw the deck. Then it plays Parasitic Strix to win the turn you pull off the combo. This deck was very mean with a god hand (which let it pull it off turn 1). The best part about it was that sense aluren allows you to play the creatures with flash you could kill them with the combo in response to them stopping it. The only exception would be if they use counters or split second. And thats why the deck ran its own.

25927: Lava Zombie.author: majinara
25927: Lava Zombie.text_parsed:
It's a nice card in any black red deck using creatures with come into play effects.
Like chittering rats or hellhole rats or flametongue kavu.

Manacurve wise, the best would be:
turn 2 ravenous rats
turn 3 attack with rats, then play this zombie and return rats to hand
turn 4 attack with zombie, pump it by one and use the other 2 mana to replay the rats.
Then you have dealt 6 damage and made your opponent discard two cards by turn 4. It's not tournament quality but very solid for casual.

In the late game or slow multiplayer game, if the zombie get's killed, you can play a gravedigger to get such a zombie back from your gy. Then replay it, return the gravedigger to hand, replay the digger, return another such zombie from your gy to hand until you have all lavazombies back, and then replay the digger another time for another creature.

The zombie needs badly trample though, so a loxodon warhammer or o-naginata might help. With the naginata it's a 7/3 trampler attacking on turn 4.

25932: Dromar's Cavern.author: tavaritz
25932: Dromar's Cavern.text_parsed:
Let's look these lairs this way:

1. If you only have lairs in your hand, mulligan.
2. Play the lairs only if you have no other land drop, remember to float the mana from the unsummoned land.
3. If you played a lair you have a land drop for the next turn also.
4. If you draw a land on the turn after you played the lair, you have a land drop for the next turn also.
5. Eventually you lose because you only draw lands for the rest of the game or you don't draw a land.
6. If you don't draw a land you can play a land because you have one in yor hand.
7. Now you have done all manadrops you could have done even if the lair wasn't a lair and you have access to the lairs mana or you have lost because you get land screwed drawing nothing but.

So are they useable in 3+ color deck or not?

use this with madness cards.

grave scrabbler negates both the return to hand and discard, AND tacks on a raise dead affect. net result: extra 4/4 on field 1 less card in opponent's hand. Effectively you're +2 cards, one of which is a 4/4 beatstick.

6 mana for a 4/4 cantrip that requires other cards is the type of thing that is gilbic.

25936: Crosis's Catacombs.author: InternetNinjacy
25936: Crosis's Catacombs.text_parsed:
Draws comparison to Crumbling Necropolis ultimately the both cause you to not have a land for a turn. The difference being that this lets you have the color you might need immediately while Crumbling Necropolis makes you wait a turn. Also, if it's REALLY necessary you can actually play this, tap it for mana, then choose not to return the other land to your hand.

You still get the mana, but this land gets sacrificed. Options, even bad options, are always good.

25936: Crosis's Catacombs.author: djflo
25936: Crosis's Catacombs.text_parsed:
If you want to play something on your turn, you can actually tap the land you're going to return for mana and then play this. With that mana still floating, your mana is as good as if you'd played a normal land, even better than if you've played a tapped land.

However, the turn after, and every subsequent turn, you'll be one land behind - that's where the slowdown comes in.

25938: Darigaaz's Caldera.author: holgir
25938: Darigaaz's Caldera.text_parsed:
The good thing about the lair lands is that you don't lose tempo on the turn they come into play because you can float mana of the land you return to your hand. The downside is that you "lost" a land drop for all subsequent turns.
In most cases the tri-lands from Shards of Alara are better (you abandon one mana the turn you play them instead of a land which comes into play untapped) but the lairs still have their uses like bouncing cycle lands, Gemstone Mine or Llanowar Reborn etc. later in the game.
The bouncelands from Ravnica block help you to hit your land drop each round, give you the possible bouncing benefit of a lair land but involve the risk of getting sort of two-for-oned if they get bounced or destroyed. Early on they can hinder your development and force you to discard down to seven.
I think Zendikar with its new keyword Landfall will strongly promote the reevaluation of all bouncelands (a bounceland like Dimir Aqueduct gives you guaranteed land drop each turn, that is if you bounce itself back each time you play it).

25938: Darigaaz's Caldera.author: SecretLan
25938: Darigaaz's Caldera.text_parsed: I have 5 of these and 5 of the Zendikar triple lands in my Sliver EDH deck. I originally only had one lair as a spot holder for a Zendikar triple, but after playing with them I realized that they were actually pretty playable. Most of the time I just waited until they were the last land in my hand to cast them anyway, so it didn't really make a difference unless I happened to draw a land next turn. I think they are pretty underrated and I am surprised they don't pop up in more EDH decks, to be honest.

25938: Darigaaz's Caldera.author: tavaritz
25938: Darigaaz's Caldera.text_parsed:
Here's my continuing saga of multilands in Magic, which I started in Castle Sengir.

So, after this colorfest the multilands (including lands that not necessarily produce multiple colors of mana but help otherways to diversify mana production) to follow were:

Seventh edition: City of Brass and Ice Age painlands (Adarkar Wastes etc.)
Apocalypse: Enemy color painlands (Battlefield Forge etc.).
Odyssey: Crystal Quarry, Deserted Temple, Tarnished Citadel, mono color lands that could sac for any color (Abandoned Outpost etc.) and allied color filter lands (Darkwater Catacombs etc.)
Torment: Tainted lands (Tainted Field etc.)
Judgment: Krosan Verge and Riftstone Portal.
Onslaught: Grand Coliseum and allied color fetchlands (Bloodstained Mire etc.)
Legions: No lands.
Scourge: No color producing lands.
Eight editon: City of Brass and Invasion comes in tapped allied color lands (Coastal Tower etc.)
Mirrodin: Glimmervoid.
Darksteel: Mirrodin's Core.
Fifth Dawn: No lands.
Champions of Kamigawa: Forbidden Orchard and allied color taplands (Cloudcrest Lake etc.)
Betrayers of Kamigawa : Tendo Ice Bridge.
Saviors of Kamigawa: No multilands.
Ninth edition: Ice Age and Apocalypse painlands (Adarkar Wastes and Battlefield Forge etc.)
Ravnica: City of Guilds : , , and versions of pay life or comes in tapped dual lands (Overgrown Tomb etc.) and comes in tapped two mana lands (Boros Garrison etc.)
Guildpact: , and versions of pay life or comes in tapped dual lands (Godless Shrine etc.) and comes in tapped two mana lands (Gruul Turf etc.)
Dissension: Pillar of the Paruns and , and versions of pay life or comes in tapped dual lands (Blood Crypt etc.) and comes in tapped two mana lands (Azorius Chancery etc.)

Ok, that's the second colorfest with new dual lands. Dual lands being lands that are two basic lands at the same time and thus fetchable with something like Bloodstained Mire and affected by something like Boil.

I continue this series in Pillar of the Paruns.

25940: Treva's Ruins.author: AssKickingBoots
25940: Treva's Ruins.text_parsed: An uncommon use of Lair lands like this is in a landfall deck to return lands to your hand for the purpose of replaying them. This is especially useful in tandem with cards that allow you to play additional lands in a turn, like Oracle of Mul Daya or Azusa, Lost but Seeking. You can also use it to replay lands that give you a benefit when they come enter the battlefield, such as Khalni Garden or Sejiri Refuge and other refuge cards. Lastly, you can use Lairs to renew counters on land cards that come into play with counters on them, like Vivid Grove or Llanowar Reborn.

25943: Bog Down.author: majinara
25943: Bog Down.text_parsed:
First:
- this is better than mind rot. It's not a great card, but better than mind rot. Mind rot has a better rating because newbies don't look that often at old cards. So more newbies look at m10 and are more easily impressed by mind rot and thus rate it higher.

- it's better than fugue. fugue has only one mode: discard 3 for 5, which is bad. This can discard 2 for 3, or 3 for 3 with kicker. It's more versatile.

- also, bog down can be used with other cards, like rumbling aftershocks or saproling infestation. You can also sac lands that you just steal temporarily, like with herald of leshrac

So in short: it's no great card, but better than mind rot and can be comboed with other stuff.

25943: Bog Down.author: blurrymadness
25943: Bog Down.text_parsed:
Situation that you use the kicker:
-You run a 1-2 drop aggro deck
-You have 3 lands on the field and one in hand => too many lands. Drop two lands to dismantle your non-blue opponent


Further:
-You play Nihilith and/or Tombstalker and/or threshold

This isn't a bad card if you're trying to lock an opponent down. 3 cards is a ton to lose. Mix this with any kind of land hate and kill cards and your opponent will quickly be down to topdecking. IF you build your deck out of gravecrawlers, removal, this, delirium skeins , raven's crime, etc.. Smallpox like this card/deck as well.

You are play this in a highly aggressive deck that doesn't give your opponent an inch to breath. Hymn goes in the same deck too. The deck is about trying to force them to play on 2-3 lands with you, but ensuring that your aggro creatures hit home with kill spells and card advantage.

25979: Meteor Crater.author: majinara
25979: Meteor Crater.text_parsed:
That's correct xyric. If you have no colored permanents, then this land can't produce any mana (not even colorless).

I like the art of this card, but... first I don't get the flavor. A meteor crashed, creating a deformed landscape. Why would then having a blue enchantment for example make the meteor crater produce black mana? Is it because the landscape is supposed to be vulnerable after the impact to any kind of influence? I don't get it. Also, it's fairly week. Not horrible, but still. At least it's not legendary.

I guess it's good in decks with shared fate or ornate kazashi, where you play cards from your opponents deck, since it lets you easier get access to the colors of that players deck.

25980: Terminal Moraine.author: Brazz_Herald
25980: Terminal Moraine.text_parsed:
Wait, wait... this land allows you to tap for mana on the turn it comes into play. If you were only splashing another color, that's excellent. You don't slow down, and you can gear up to play your big spell (or your answers like Naturalize a little later).

So why does card of the day consider "trying to provide mana itself" a mistake? Perhaps, from a design perspective, Terramorphic Expanse is a cleaner card. But if they printed Terminal Moraine in a set where you want to splash to achieve minor effects in a second or third color, it would fit well. This design was perfect for Planeshift, where players were doing just that... trying to squeeze a third color in so they could play a powerful Tri-Spell, or sneaking one more basic land in for domain...
25980: Terminal Moraine.text_posted:

I have trouble deciding wether or not it is better than Underworld Dreams. On one hand Pyrexian Tyranny affects both you and your opponents (unless they pay), and as you proceed into the late game it begins to loose steam (as each player has 8-10 lands to spare).
Still... it provides some vicious combos and, if used in burn deck fashion, function as a death clock (2 damage per turn). It provides an fun tag team with Kederekt Parasite who needs a red permanent to operate, and can technically knock out a tapped out opponent in turn 4 with Wheel and Deal. Call to Heel could find its way into this deck. Just make sure you dont create a deck based on Pyrexian Tyranny.

26286: Quirion Dryad.author: jonb86
26286: Quirion Dryad.text_parsed: About 9 years ago, this creature was the key win condition of the most powerful pre-2002 rotation Extended deck of it's Day; Miracle Gro (a pun on the popular plant federalizer).  Those days are long gone and this card as faded into the oblivion of nearly unplayable creature cards.  It's still a good creature to add to a 5-color EDH deck.  But in modern Legacy; Gro just doesn't cut it these days (I see it played once in a blue moon, but it never does that well against a quality archetype Legacy deck).  If I ever see the creature played and/or get counters I always heckle "Gro Dryad Gro!".

26288: Strafe.author: casualhorror
26288: Strafe.text_parsed: This is removal that I'd be pleased to find in my sealed or pick in draft at some point. That is all it is. And yes, Sunlance is a better card because it does have a niche that isn't just 1 cost removal. That is a removal spell for that doesn't give a land or life while still having further restrictions to your opponent. I'm not sure that it is good enough for that niche use to justify its play that much in say Modern, but it isn't as if there is no reason to. I'd probably play Sunlanceover Oustin the decks that would consider forgoing Path to Exile. Meanwhile a card like this is facing a strictly better card and that card may well be the best Magic card until you hit Vintage. The improved version has done about as much in Modern as Sunlance has.

I can see these bruisers swimming to victory in games the world over.

26381: Mana Cylix.author: Stinga
26381: Mana Cylix.text_parsed: @DrJack He is simply shoehorning "card disadvantage" into the flavor text. And, while the card does not say anything about discarding it *does* make card disadvantage. This card only fixes your mana, thus does not impact the game state. Thus you are spending a card to achieve nothing, basically discarding it when you could be doing something. While I don't agree that the card is useless (Metalvolence would be begging for one of these instead of the seventh forest in his White/Green/Blue deck) that the card is useless I do agree that it does not actually contribute to your position. So I see where he is coming from. About the card itself, sorta meh. As has allready been beaten-to-death the card only does work when you need to fix mana and I would rather just run dual lands or land search or mana dudes or whatever, depending on the deck. Still, it is not a terrible card. 2/5

26396: Primal Growth.author: Shasticus
26396: Primal Growth.text_parsed:
No one seems have mentioned the (second) easiest abuse with this card, so I think I will.

Sacrifice this to a Viridian Emissary. Veteran explorer is sweet, but it also helps out the other guy(s) at the table. While that may net you some 'I won't hate on you' points for a few turns, the potential drawback in case some *** is playing something silly (like infinite myr (especially now a days..)) is pretty high. Besides, I'm a greedy guy, I don't want to share my glorious land fetching, do you?

A personal favorite I've been wanting to try as gone something like this, keep in mind the deck revolves around playing out the forests as quickly as possible for Avenger of Zendikar and Howl of the night pack.

Turn 1: Forest and arbor elf(2 lands, effectively)
Turn 2: Tap and untap a forest for a Khalni heart expedition, forest and play Krosan warfarer sac it into another forest. (Keep in mind you now have 4 forests)

Turn 3: Forest, Viridian Emissary, play out this, sac the emissary to it. Pop your expedition for the lulz whenever. You now have 10 lands on turn 3, 11 if you have a nature's lore available to you.

This is obviously never happen unless you're stupid lucky, but isn't the fun of commenting on cards all about hypothetical scenarios anyway? Oh, and that entire time you've had a fog or some such nonsense in your hand.

I suppose you could hold off on the expedition, play the avenger you've had(instead of the fog) and then pop it while you play your basic land.. 8-9 nice meaty 3/4 plants and a beefy 5/5 all on turn 4..

..Then the other guy wraths and you flip the table.

26403: Surprise Deployment.author: blurrymadness
26403: Surprise Deployment.text_parsed:
@Bigg_ol & WrathofShane
Reiver says you must "cast" him, this says "put into play." There's a reason the restriction the demon exists.

There is no combo with Reiver demon, and there *are* viritually no combos with him except mana ramp. Take this from a guy who puts demons into any deck that runs black.


The reason this isn't "broken" and merely "good" are:
-It doesn't cause the creature to die, which is a coveted trigger (think Flash Hulk decks), Flash does do that
-This doesn't cost 2 mana. 4 is quite reasonable for this considering that the best you'll ever get is a Wrath effect, but that costs 4 mana anyway. (Note: Sunblast Angel makes an excellent combo with this)
-This opens you up for easy two-for-ones. While it has potential to be card neutral, if the opponent has removal ready or his own combat trick you may just spend two cards to have the opponent spend one and save his creature anyway.
-This can't be used offensively. At all. Even with Haste. Sad times :( :( :(

26407: Sisay's Ingenuity.author: wooded_taint
26407: Sisay's Ingenuity.text_parsed:
@James
Good question. the answer is yes. In the right deck, this card is the s**t. I had a cousin who got me into magic and ran an all color deck with familiars and everything about 7 years ago. In a deck with lots of creatures with protection from different colors, things like "when this creature comes into play, return a (insert color here) creature to your hand," and other, this card is pretty nice. A lot of people have forgotten that in the olden days a ton more cards were color specific, and this card was just one of the engines that made those color specific cards work with all colors.

26411: Gaea's Herald.author: Internet_decks_lame
26411: Gaea's Herald.text_parsed:
Obviously will never make main deck in any situation. But considering where the battlefield of Magic is heading... We have so many powerful 2 cmc creatures that have game tilting effects. And it seems counter magic will always be a staple of any competitive tournament. This creature forces a counter magic player to exhaust a card very quickly in order to maintain control. Although the downside would be, your deck has to be exclusive to mostly creatures to effectively take up sideboard slots. Not to mention, this creature needs to be played early to maintain the balance against a counter magic player. Drawing this late game, while a counter magic player has already established control would be very unfortunate. May be better to just run Great Sable Stag, or Thrun, the last Troll to beat down the heavy counter spell decks. I would not rule this guy out completely... but if you choose to run him, you should really get familiar with your pool of competitive players and how many of them are counter spell freaks. But if you don't want to take it from me, every top 8 players in every tournament is usually comprised of 50% or greater, of some kind of counter magic/control.

3/5

Could use a better body like 2/1. Anything that reads... Can't be countered is beautiful. Took wizards about 15 years to finally understand blue always makes top 8 and even when you print anti blue, if it doesn't read "can't be countered" then its NOT REALLY anti blue.

I wonder why this awesome lady doesn't have awe-inspiring flavor text as her other angelic companions (Voice of Truth, Voice of Reason, Voice of Grace, Voice of Law, and Voice of Duty) have.
Even Serra Avenger have a flavor text referring to the Song of All.
Maybe these angels actually have nothing to do with each the Voice of All? I doubt it, but it could be true.

Anyways, regarding the playability of the card, it is awesome. It deters attackers, avoids removal, and strikes unblockable against mono-colored decks. Works a bit less smooth against multicolor decks but those usually are dominated by one color of the deck, so it's usually a simple choice anyways. Simply awesome for casual in a white control deck, together with maybe Blinding Angel?
4.5/5

26420: Heroic Defiance.author: blurrymadness
26420: Heroic Defiance.text_parsed:
Auras, even with a cheap-for-cost effect like this, are often also not worth it without evasion. It's not just card advantage and other issues, look at the top auras! They have all have Trample, Flying, and/or another buff and at reasonable mana costs, before you consider the other good pieces of the card often attached.

This may give you some quick beats in a white artifact deck, but you'll need to be careful building the deck in order to get this to do much.

26422: Diabolic Intent.author: JaxsonBateman
26422: Diabolic Intent.text_parsed:
Got pointed to this after making a thread about tutors, and not noticing this one... because it didn't have the word tutor in it. But WOW. In a world where creatures already provide card advantage just be entering the battlefield, and hundreds of token creatures flying about every which way, this kind of card is just awesome, given that even if you are playing vintage you can only have 1 Demonic Tutor.

I've been working on a BG deck which, amongst others, includes Nest Invader, Kozilek's Predator and Grave Titan, and a way to recur them repeatedly. So sacrificing ONE token creature is by no means a big requirement when the upside involves getting ANY card that I want or need out of my deck.

Not for every deck, but great in the decks that can work it. And to offset the card disadvantage from the creature sacrifice, always consider black's lovable Grave Pact. ^^

26422: Diabolic Intent.author: Domislice
26422: Diabolic Intent.text_parsed:
Amazing tutor that doesn't seem to be well known, probably because it doesn't have "tutor" in the name, and I guess isn't quite fast enough in most situations to be banned (as it obviously stalls you the sacrificed creature).

Still a first turn one mana creature drop, second turn attack and then sac to this for any card is a great play that can change a bad draw into a good one, particularly with other graveyard orientated cards. Works brilliantly in my Legacy Zombie deck with Gravecrawler and Unearth. Also is superb with Tragic Slip and any deck already featuring Diabolic Intent should 100% have both.

5/5 card no doubt.

26422: Diabolic Intent.author: ParallaxtheRevan
26422: Diabolic Intent.text_parsed:
Deaderpool: They don't make Animate Dead's anyMORE, but RnD knew that Odyssey Block was in the works, and there are a lot of cards that interact unfairly with this there, but they designed Threshold so that it would be better for you to have cards in your graveyard than anywhere else. This still would have been considered an extremely broken combo piece back in that day. Between Urza's Block and Odyssey Block, almost every powerful Reanimation Tool EXCEPT Animate Dead would have been in Extended at the same time, I think, and very nearly missed being in Standard together. Mercadian Masques kept them apart though. Still, all these cards were floating around the casual scene tearing up people with anything and everything with Power and Toughness, by like Turn 2? 3? 4?

We don't get LD or Reanimation at the CMC we used to, they're BOTH close to about 5-6 now?
Although on a very good Block we can get passable Reanimation at 4, and that happens...uncommonly, but if you stick around long enough you'll see it again.

This card is two mana-- at an ADDITIONAL mana it wouldn't see reprint, but it would still rock. At double the mana cost, it would be a tossup but I think people would still make it to Top 8s in Standard with it.

26477: Phyrexian Scuta.author: Mode
26477: Phyrexian Scuta.text_parsed:
@makochman:
One could argue whether Juzám Djinn or Phyrexian Scuta is better.
Generally the Djinn will be worse after your fourth upkeep, before that you'll have lost your life slower so if you just need him for two attacks he's preferable.
This would only be the case though if you assume that either...
-your opponent will have used removal on him in time (which, albeit annoying, sounds quite plausible)
-you have won the game at that point (which is unlikely)
-you have some way to get rid of him (which would be dumb)
-you have some way to prevent the damage, like Personal Sanctuary (which is the only case where i'd prefer Juzám).

The Scuta has more upsides by himself:
-he can also be played as a Hill Giant if you don't need him to be 5/5, or if you don't want or can't even afford to lose any life, making him more flexible.
Further deck-specific advantages:
-he costs just one black mana. That makes him easier to cast in a deck with multiple colors - again, more flexibility.
-he's a Zombie, making him a nice target for tribal decks - with Undead Warchief for example you'll have the choice to get a 5/4 or a 7/6 by just paying three mana.


But you can't really compare this dude to Phyrexian Negator in the first place. They're simply two different cards.
Phyrexian Scuta isn't meant as a finisher, and the days where you could rely on Juzám Djinn as one are long gone.

26478: Noxious Vapors.author: Andon_A
26478: Noxious Vapors.text_parsed:
There are very few situations in which this card is not good, and there are many in which it is excellent.

It kills all non-land colorless cards. It nukes hands of mono-colored decks. It's very solid against two color decks, and even against five-color decks, how often do they have a card of each color?

Its largest shortcoming is dealing with multicolored cards, but aside from that it's quite solid. A good addition to a discard deck, because you're almost guaranteed two or more cards for three mana, which seems to be the going rate for discard.

26480: Skyship Weatherlight.author: adrian.malacoda
26480: Skyship Weatherlight.text_parsed:
@MasterOfBearLore

No. Mycosynth Lattice only turns permanents into artifacts. Permanents are objects that exist on the battlefield. The cards exiled by Mana Severance are cards, not permanents, because they do not exist on the battlefield. Mycosynth Lattice will not turn those land cards into artifact cards.
26480: Skyship Weatherlight.text_posted:

26590: Ertai's Trickery.author: Salient

This isn't even good in Poetry Limited, which limits you to cards whose current rules text happens to be written in meter, like iambic pentameter. (Thanks, Oracle update!)

It would not surprise me to learn that there are game stores -- heck, entire regions of the globe -- in which nobody has ever resolved this spell.

Even at the time, folks mostly said, "so it doesn't even counter a spell with kicker unless they kicked it?! Oh forget this nonsense." And back then it wasn't even poetic!

26833: Lashknife Barrier.author: Vinifera7
26833: Lashknife Barrier.text_parsed:
@A3Kitsune:
Not really, no. This doesn't technically "prevent" the damage like Absorb does. If, for example, your creature was hit with Banefire (with an X of 5 or more), Lashknife Barrier will still reduce the total damage by 1, regardless of the fact that the damage can't be prevented.

It's like the difference between shuffling cards and putting cards in a random order. The action is the same, but the former is called "shuffling" so it gets special rules interactions.

26852: Orim's Chant.author: Uril
26852: Orim's Chant.text_parsed: Not to be a jerk, but it doesn't combo with hissing miasma and pyrostatic pillar, those just do semi similar things. If you played this, then during that turn, those cards would be useless. Also, this doesn't stop storm, because storm copies the spells, it doesn't play them again. Furthermore, you can still cast spells with this on the stack, so any instants can be played before this resolves. Despite that, it is a very good card, and with it's more recent counterpart silence, there could be a viable deck with these and Isochron Scepter and maybe some permission for the spells that seep through at instant speed.
26852: Orim's Chant.text_posted: Not to be a jerk, but it doesn't combo with [autocard]hissing miasma[/autocard] and [autocard]pyrostatic pillar[/autocard], those just do semi similar things. 26852: Orim's Chant.author: GainsBanding
26852: Orim's Chant.text_parsed: This stops storm not by countering all the copied spells (because, as Uril pointed out, it does not do that) but by keeping the storm player from casting enough to cast a lethal storm.  If you respond to two Dark Rituals with this, then they can't cast their Ad Nauseam until they find more mana.  Or if you respond to Ad Nauseam with this, they can draw all those cards, but they'll have to wait till next turn to use them and possibly discard if they draw too many. Etc etc.
26852: Orim's Chant.text_posted: This stops storm not by countering all the copied spells (because, as Uril pointed out, it does not do that) but by keeping the storm player from casting enough to cast a lethal storm.  If you respond to two Dark Rituals with this, then they can't cast their Ad Nauseam until they find more mana.  Or if you respond to Ad Nauseam with this, they can draw all those cards, but they'll have to wait till next turn to use them and possibly discard if they draw too many. Etc etc.

26852: Orim's Chant.author: blurrymadness
26852: Orim's Chant.text_parsed:
It's worth noting that this targets a player and that silence does not. In some sense this is more powerful in general, but it's a lot easier to counter and to block because it has to target a person. Silence doesn't care about anything on the field unless it's a counter-target spell/instant.

This is still generally better, but strictly better it isn't. It's not the same rules text; it doesn't function the same; so it's not comparable in the sense of "Strictly".

@GainsBanding
That's not true. This must resolve to stop storm. Now, it IS true that you can eat up their dark rituals, but I personally don't use those for my storm count as I'm a Brain Freeze guy. I just do high tide shenanigans. The most you'll eat of mine before I either quit for the turn or just combo anyway is something like a snap or a high tide. Indeed useful, but often not enough to really stop a combo.

27634: Questing Phelddagrif.author: majinara
27634: Questing Phelddagrif.text_parsed:
- it's a 4/4 for four mana without a drawback, which is fine
- the lifegain is not optional. with false cure it means: "w: target opponent loses 2 life"
- the tokens are not optional for your opponent. I had a deck using this guy + engineered plague set to "hippo" + tainted aether. since the tokens die before the trigger of the aether resolves, the result of the combo was "g: target opponent sacrifices a creature or land". priceless to see the reactions of opponents, when they first laugh on the plague set to "hippo", and suddenly their permanents are gone
- with Pledge of Loyality it gains protection from green, blue and white, and for w it also gain's protection from black and red
- with enough mana, you can pump this guy up with green mana and kill your opponent. since you can also gives the hippo flying, your opponent won't be able to block with the tokens he gets (so who cares about them), and if your opponent got a flier, it can only block if neither red nor black, since you could just give the hippo protection
- no bad card for multiplayer politics. everyone knows you will activate it, and those who annoyed you least will then gain tokens, life and cards

Fine card all around.

27634: Questing Phelddagrif.author: bobothegoat
27634: Questing Phelddagrif.text_parsed:
Honestly, I often compare this card to Morphling. Protection from black and red doesn't help vs pacifism effects and such, but otherwise might as well be Morphling's "shroud until end of turn" ability for most removal, and the 2 life gain for your opponent is fairly negligible. Pumping with green mana giving the opponent free creatures is unfortunate, but you can get around it by giving the hippo flying (hopefully, if you're doing this you're pretty much doing lethal damage anyway), and also using the pump effect after the declare blockers phase (so you don't get chump blocked by a hippo...). Otherwise, it's very similar to the +1/-1 and -1/+1--better once the new combat rules take effect.

Though, I must also be honest... Phelddagrif with pemmin's aura (so it actually IS a stronger morphling) is also really awesome, if mostly pointless.

Not surprisingly, it's also one of the coolest cards you can ever cast in a multiplayer game. People love these hippo tokens, and anyone who doesn't has no soul. Therefor, you get people doing favors for you in hopes that they can get some free hippos or life-gain, or even card draws while you smash someone elses faces in with your super awesome flying hippo. It's like a slightly worse morphling, but also better since it's a frickin' hippo with wings.

Protection from black and red doesn't help vs pacifism effects and such, but otherwise might as well be Morphling's "shroud until end of turn" ability for most removal, and the 2 life gain for your opponent is fairly negligible.  Pumping with green mana giving the opponent free creatures is unfortunate, but you can get around it by giving the hippo flying (hopefully, if you're doing this you're pretty much doing lethal damage anyway), and also using the pump effect after the declare blockers phase (so you don't get chump blocked by a hippo...).  Otherwise, it's very similar to the +1/-1 and -1/+1--better once the new combat rules take effect.

Though, I must also be honest... Phelddagrif with pemmin's aura (so it actually IS a stronger morphling) is also really awesome, if mostly pointless.

Not surprisingly, it's also one of the coolest cards you can ever cast in a multiplayer game.  People love these hippo tokens, and anyone who doesn't has no soul.  Therefor, you get people doing favors for you in hopes that they can get some free hippos or life-gain, or even card draws while you smash someone elses faces in with your super awesome flying hippo.  It's like a slightly worse morphling, but also better since it's a frickin' hippo with wings.

27634: Questing Phelddagrif.author: Ideatog
27634: Questing Phelddagrif.text_parsed:
I feel that the regular Phelddagrif is better.

-Both have a 'gains flying ability' which allows the hippo to get by blockers, probably dealing 4 dmg. On the original, this was offset be giving the opponent 2 life (2<4). On this version, you give them a card (possibly a greater advantage than 2 life)

-Both have a protective ability: 'protection from R/B' or 'return to hand'. The protection ability only protects from R/B, and you give them 2 life, which isn't a bad price and the phelddagrif does stay in play. Returning to hand your opponent a card (net card advantage 0) but protects fro meverything except discard.

-Old Phelddagrif gives the opp. a 1/1 in exchange for trample. If that hippo was the only blocker as the cost seems to suggest (Hunted Dragon style) then 3 dmg still gets through. Whereas the new phelddagrif gives a 1/1 and gets a timy +1/+1 bump, which is not only negated completely by the 1/1, but also doesn't last as long.

End of rant.

29291: Tahngarth, Talruum Hero.author: MithosFall
29291: Tahngarth, Talruum Hero.text_parsed:
@Condor_96: No, his ability isn't the same as fight. Tahngarth deals his damage to the targeted creature first and then that creature hits Tahngarth. Usually it wouldn't matter, but in the event of Tahngarth having Wither or Infect, it'll change the targeted creature's power and possibly make it unable to kill Tahngarth as a result.

@sarroth: State-based actions are only ever checked just before a player would get priority (i.e. able to cast spell or activate abilities). No players get priority while a spell or ability is resolving.

29293: Skyship Weatherlight.author: Wormfang
29293: Skyship Weatherlight.text_parsed:
Take my love, Take my land
Take me where I cannot stand
I don't care, I'm still free
You can't take the sky from me

Take me out to the black
Tell them I ain't comin' back
Burn the land and boil the sea
You can't take the sky from me.

Leave the men where they lay
They'll never see another day
Lost my soul, lost my dream
You can't take the sky from me.

I feel the black reaching out
I hear its song without a doubt
I still hear and I still see
That you can't take the sky from me.

Lost my love, lost my land
Lost the last place I could stand
There's no place I can be
Since I've found Serenity

And you can't take the sky from me.

8902: Goblin Game.author: kitsunewarlock
8902: Goblin Game.text_parsed: If you can ramp into this card (easy considering red now has the best "Mana Ritual" cards), its actually quite good. Play it with Children of Korlis or (better but more colors) Tainted Sigil to get your life back. I'd also run Plague of Vermin in this type of deck. Spend 19 life...your opponent will lose 1/2 + the amount they bid (expect good players to bid only 1 life, if not zero), then get back 24+ life. Korlis stack too.

8902: Goblin Game.author: TopRomen
8902: Goblin Game.text_parsed:
@murdershot21: It says in the errata, "When it comes to choice of items, use common sense. Items should be small enough to hide but large enough to count. Make it clear what kind of object you are hiding beforehand. For example, one player may choose coins and the other may choose dice. If you can't find something convenient to hide, write numbers on a piece of paper and reveal the numbers. Make sure the numbers are unambiguous (for example, underline a 6 or 9 so it can't be misread)."

Another interesting piece of errata: "If you attempt to halve a negative life total, you halve 0. This means that the life total stays the same. A life total of -10 would remain -10."

Doesn't seem very relevant, but I guess it could save someone if they played a life gain card as an interrupt. Speaking of which... Based on the wording of this card, you could potentially play instants in response to someone revealing their item.

"I have a penci - "

"SUDDEN DEATH!!!"

"... Why?"

"I just wanted to play in response to a physical action in magic. Just once."
8902: Goblin Game.text_posted:
@murdershot21: It says in the errata, "When it comes to choice of items, use common sense. Items should be small enough to hide but large enough to count. Make it clear what kind of object you are hiding beforehand. For example, one player may choose coins and the other may choose dice. If you can't find something convenient to hide, write numbers on a piece of paper and reveal the numbers. Make sure the numbers are unambiguous (for example, underline a 6 or 9 so it can't be misread)."

Another interesting piece of errata: "If you attempt to halve a negative life total, you halve 0.  This means that the life total stays the same.  A life total of -10 would remain -10."

Doesn't seem very relevant, but I guess it could save someone if they played a life gain card as an interrupt. Speaking of which... Based on the wording of this card, you could potentially play instants in response to someone revealing their item.

"I have a penci - "

"SUDDEN DEATH!!!"

"... Why?"

"I just wanted to play in response to a physical action in magic. Just once."

8902: Goblin Game.author: draco_nite
8902: Goblin Game.text_parsed: @TopRomen: No, you couldn't do that. The revealing of the items is part of the spell's resolution, and you can't do things in response to other things while spells resolve.
8902: Goblin Game.text_posted: @TopRomen: No, you couldn't do that. The revealing of the items is part of the spell's resolution, and you can't do things in response to other things while spells resolve.

8902: Goblin Game.author: majinara
8902: Goblin Game.text_parsed:
In short, this card reads: "each player loses a good chunk of life", which is obviously better than damage since it can't be prevented. It also puts players in a lose/lose situation. If they bid too much they have about lost anyway, and if they don't, then they lose even more.

Edit: CpmCrunch, nah, it doesn't break MTGO. The game client simply asks people to pick a number. At least last time I played goblin game on MTGO it worked that well just fine.

8902: Goblin Game.author: kiseki
8902: Goblin Game.text_parsed:
Cheatyface only allows you to sneak it into play FROM YOUR HAND. If they notice as soon as they come back from a 5 min search, that counts, and they are exiled.

Source: Un-rules manager Mark Rosewater
http://markrosewater.tumblr.com/post/66850669579/un-rules-question-am-i-allowed-to-sneak-cheatyface
http://markrosewater.tumblr.com/post/20352664853/in-the-same-vein-as-cheatyface-questions-can-you-cheat

However, I applaud your efforts to collect so many.

9690: Destructive Flow.author: Salient
9690: Destructive Flow.text_parsed:
This card was brutal in its standard time and saw a revival

Play with Dakmor Salvage and Life from the Loam, slow-rolling it until you accumulate some basics. Don't forget about Mox Diamond, too.

That's Dredge control for you. Of course, Dredge is much more powerful as aggro, so you don't see many people playing Dredge control. But you could. And this card isn't a bad place to start.
